title: Ticket #3371: Create authorization ping tool
description:
It's quite useful to be able to invoke an "echo" command on a remote condor daemon to see which authorizations the current user has.

This suggestion is from experience - this has been extraordinarily useful in the Globus world, as it allows sysadmins to test the functionality of their site's authorization setup.

We've had many folks complain about the complexity of configuring Condor authorization - a mechanism like this will help people test their own sites.

Current Milestone: Create design document and actual milestones. Due 1/16/2013.
remarks:
2013-Jan-23 19:00:25 by bbockelm:
Hi ZKM,

Comments from reading the design document:

  • I'm worried about just supporting "-addr". I'd really want to have "-name" and "-pool" available too. "-config" is also slightly non-standard, but I like it.
  • Can you give a few mockups of the CLI and corresponding output?
    • Will you print out the encryption and integrity level required? Etc.

Brian

2013-Jan-28 16:26:48 by zmiller:
brian:

for the first pass, it's definitely going to support only "-addr". i understand the desire for more convenience, ("-pool, -name") but there a few problems with having to contact the collector first, though none are insurmountable.

1) would "-name" work for schedds, startds, negotiators, ad_i_just_made_up? we'd also then need a subsystem since "foo.cs.wisc.edu" could well be the name of a master and a startd.

2) if we can't get the address from the collector for some reason, we haven't really done what the user asked. the error message would need to be exceedingly clear about this. should it then report on the attempt to talk to the collector?

3) it's definitely possible that the security policy on the collector is different than the target daemon. i really want the tool to focus on the target daemon, and not (at least at first) have some convoluted setup where you would potentially have to pass in two different security mechanisms to deal with two different daemons.

4) not all daemons register with the collector, so "-addr" is necessary anyways.

if this is a huge problem, i propose to solve it for now with a wrapper script. first query the collector and get the address you want: 

  condor_status -schedd -const 'Name=="$1"' -format "%s\n" MyAddress

if succesful, that yields the sinful string you are after, which could then be passed to the ping tool.

if it's not successful, then maybe the tool would wish to diagnose the collector's security settings.

in any case, we can extend it with command line API sugar once the tool is written and works. for now i just want to go with something very straightforward, which is to connect directly to the daemon. like i said, none of the above problems are without solutions, but let's get something workable done first. thanks for the feedback!

2013-Feb-28 09:08:18 by bbockelm:
Hi Zach,

I got around to spinning a new condor build and can't figure out how to make things work. 

[bbockelm@hcc-briantest fedpkg-condor-hcc]$ /usr/sbin/condor_check_security -addr '<red-condor.unl.edu:9619>'
Missing <authz-level | command-name | command-int> argument, defaulting to DC_NOP

Suggestions?

2013-Feb-28 09:14:06 by zmiller:
hi brian,

the -addr argument takes <ip.ad.dr.ess:port> (no hostnames allowed).

so -addr <129.93.239.155:9619> should work.

allowing dns names (and -pool and -name) is on the to-do list for improvements.

2013-Feb-28 10:48:01 by bbockelm:
Hi Zach,

Can we include an error message when the sinful string is invalid?

Anyhow, starting to point things at the Nebraska collector (allows read-only access or GSI). Here's what I get with an expired proxy: 

[bbockelm@hcc-briantest fedpkg-condor-hcc]$ /usr/sbin/condor_check_security -address '<129.93.239.155:9618>'
Missing <authz-level | command-name | command-int> argument, defaulting to DC_NOP

AUTHENTICATE:1003:Failed to authenticate with any method
AUTHENTICATE:1004:Failed to authenticate using GSI
GSI:5003:Failed to authenticate.  Globus is reporting error (851968:14).  There is probably a problem with your credentials.  (Did you run grid-proxy-init?)

After renewing the proxy: 

[bbockelm@hcc-briantest fedpkg-condor-hcc]$ /usr/sbin/condor_check_security -address '<129.93.239.155:9618>'
Missing <authz-level | command-name | command-int> argument, defaulting to DC_NOP

Remote Version:              $CondorVersion: 7.9.2 Oct 11 2012 PRE-RELEASE-UWCS $
Local  Version:              $CondorVersion: 7.9.5 Feb 28 2013 PRE-RELEASE-UWCS $

Session ID:                  red-condor:14899:1362069240:372727
Encryption:                  none
Integrity:                   MD5
Authenticated using:         GSI
All authentication methods:  GSI
Remote Mapping:              bbockelm@unl.edu

For read: 

[bbockelm@hcc-briantest fedpkg-condor-hcc]$ /usr/sbin/condor_check_security -address '<129.93.239.155:9618>' READ
Remote Version:              $CondorVersion: 7.9.2 Oct 11 2012 PRE-RELEASE-UWCS $
Local  Version:              $CondorVersion: 7.9.5 Feb 28 2013 PRE-RELEASE-UWCS $

Session ID:                  red-condor:14899:1362069678:372748
Encryption:                  none
Integrity:                   none
Authentication:              none
Remote Mapping:              unauthenticated@unmapped

For write: 

[bbockelm@hcc-briantest fedpkg-condor-hcc]$ /usr/sbin/condor_check_security -address '<129.93.239.155:9618>' WRITE
Remote Version:              $CondorVersion: 7.9.2 Oct 11 2012 PRE-RELEASE-UWCS $
Local  Version:              $CondorVersion: 7.9.5 Feb 28 2013 PRE-RELEASE-UWCS $

Session ID:                  red-condor:14899:1362069680:372749
Encryption:                  none
Integrity:                   MD5
Authenticated using:         GSI
All authentication methods:  GSI
Remote Mapping:              bbockelm@unl.edu

Can we print out the authorization / daemon command in the output? Is it possible to include that in the output?

Were we able to do a list of all authorizations?

2013-Feb-28 11:20:41 by zmiller:
brian,

thanks for the feedback!

you wrote above: 

    >
    > Can we print out the authorization / daemon command in the output? Is it possible to include that in the output?
    >

do you mean just echo back something like: 

  For WRITE level authorization the results were:

  For command ADVERTISE_SCHEDD the results were:

you also wrote: 

    >
    > Were we able to do a list of all authorizations?
    >

at the moment, no. but i plan to add the ability to specify multiple levels/command per invocation, and a special keyword "ALL". the report would benefit from a more concise mode (maybe -table) for that type of invocation. something like: 

[zmiller@localhost]$ /usr/sbin/condor_check_security -table READ WRITE DAEMON
Authz-Level   Authentication Encryption Integrity Mapping
READ          none           none       none      unauthenticated@unmapped
WRITE         GSI            none       MD5       zmiller@cs.wisc.edu
DAEMON        GSI            none       MD5       NOT AUTHORIZED(*)

(*) this response does not yet currently exist, but i'm working on it. :)

2013-Feb-28 21:04:56 by bbockelm:
Hi Zach -

Yup, even just echo'ing out the auth level requested would be useful.

Other comments:

  • I like the idea of a "ALL", but I think making it easier to search for a specific daemon is higher on the priority list.
  • Any interest in learning how to add a python binding?

Brian

2013-Mar-01 08:24:26 by bbockelm:
Hi Zach,

A few more issues:

This doesn't work: 

[bbockelm@hcc-briantest ~]$ condor_check_security -addr '<129.79.53.146:9618>' DC_NOP
Not recognized as an authorization level, command name, or command int: DC_NOP

Further, if I ask for an authorization level I know I don't have, I get no difference in output: 

[bbockelm@hcc-briantest ~]$ condor_check_security -addr '<129.79.53.146:9618>' ADMINISTRATOR
Remote Version:              $CondorVersion: 7.8.6 Oct 25 2012 $
Local  Version:              $CondorVersion: 7.9.5 Feb 28 2013 PRE-RELEASE-UWCS $

Session ID:                  oasis:2569:1362147794:27
Encryption:                  none
Integrity:                   none
Authentication:              none
Remote Mapping:              unauthenticated@unmapped

I think knowing whether I have the authorization is an essential part to this tool.

2013-Mar-01 11:05:40 by zmiller:
hi brian,

yes, i just realized yesterday that because of the mechanism i was using, daemonCore is short-circuiting and declaring success before attempting authorization (because it knows it's not going to call any command handler, so it decides authorization doesn't matter...)

this means i'll need to do some more significant work to either add a new command handler that continues and checks authorization, or rearrange the existing code to allow authorization without then continuing with the actual command.

sorry for not letting you know yesterday -- i am working on updating the design doc to reflect this and posting a new version today. don't worry, though, we're still well on track to have this done for 7.9.5.

2013-Mar-01 11:08:36 by zmiller:
also, in regards to DC_NOP -- the table that maps commands seems to be out of date and missing some entries. i'm sure there are others besides DC_NOP. in a pinch, you can always use the command int itself if you know it.

2013-Mar-01 11:10:33 by zmiller:
in summary, you might want to wait until the next revision to do more testing. it should be significantly closer to the desired product.

2013-Mar-01 12:20:51 by bbockelm:
Ok, will do! Very sorry for not getting to testing this earlier.

2013-Apr-13 10:14:25 by bbockelm:
Hi Zach,

I see some new commits. Are things ready for testing again?

Brian

2013-Apr-13 10:53:48 by zmiller:
brian -- the new commits add the plumbing that was necessary to show whether or not a given mapping was authorized. you can certainly test that functionaly out. however other than the one new line of output (authorization succeeded), none of the other user-interface changes are in yet... i'm working on those now.

2013-Apr-13 11:00:51 by bbockelm:
Fair enough - I'll probably wait. Thanks!

2013-Apr-16 13:55:41 by zmiller:
okay, brian. this is pretty close to the final version. please test it out. i'm not crazy about the default output -- what would you like to see there? also see what you think of "condor_ping -table ALL" mode.

(fyi, this tool is not compatible with pre 7.9.6 daemons)

2013-Apr-22 08:48:03 by bbockelm:
Some feedback of the latest code.

First - this should lead to some sort of usage message: 

$ condor_ping
WARNING: Missing <authz-level | command-name | command-int> argument, defaulting to DC_NOP
DC_NOP failed!  Use -verbose for more information.

If I do "condor_ping -h", it does tell me that "-h" is an unknown argument. This goes against the normal HTCondor command-line-parsing rules.

Second - if you point this at an un-upgraded daemon, you get the following message:

(daemon side) 

04/22/13 07:44:52 (pid:5167) Received TCP command (60040) (UNREGISTERED COMMAND!) from  <129.93.244.208:38383>

(client side) 

$ condor_ping -address '<129.93.239.129:41562>' DC_NOP -verbose
DC_NOP failed!
SECMAN:2007:Failed to end classad message.

It may be reasonable to actually do a DC_NOP followed by the new command to help the transition.

Third - it appears that when "ALL" is requested, it prints out all authorizations, even if they are not meaningful for the daemon (ADVERTISE_STARTD for a Schedd). The daemon should respond with a N/A.

Fourth - I propose renaming the columns "Instruction" to "Authorization" and "Authz" to "Decision" in the table.

Fifth - If the collector is off, we have "FAIL" printed out in the table. It may be useful to print out some extra message about being unable to contact the collector.

Sixth - When in table mode, we should at least print out what daemon was contacted.

We have great potential here - this was very helpful for me to lock down my local condor.

2013-Apr-22 09:02:50 by bbockelm:
Hi Zach,

One further note - it seems impossible to make schedd WRITE authentication to report anything but ALLOW and "unauthenticated@unmapped".

Am I doing something wrong? I have: 

$ condor_ping WRITE -table
         Instruction Authentication Encryption Integrity Authz Identity
               WRITE           none       none      none ALLOW unauthenticated@unmapped

However, 

$ condor_config_val -schedd ALLOW_WRITE
root@hcc-briantest.unl.edu
$ condor_config_val -schedd DENY_WRITE
anonymous@*, unauthenticated@*

If I force integrity, it seems I can get the user to authorize - however, ALLOW_WRITE still seems to be ignored.

Puzzled,

Brian

2013-Apr-29 08:09:13 by bbockelm:
Hi ZKM,

Here's an important issue: 

[bbockelm@hcc-briantest condor-ce]$ condor_ping -pool red.unl.edu:9619 -name red.unl.edu DC_NOP
DC_NOP failed!  Use -verbose for more information.
[bbockelm@hcc-briantest condor-ce]$ echo $?
0

When condor_ping fails, it returns 0!

Brian

2013-Jun-10 14:43:32 by zmiller:
As the bulk of the work was done and released in 8.0.0, and I incorporated most of the suggestions from comments along the way, I am resolving this ticket. Any further modifications should get new tickets.
